property.name: text
property.value: Author: Chihhong Patrick Cheng, iRobotHillClimbing model by Edward A. Lee

property.name: text
property.value:
For details regarding this example, please reference the technical report http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Pubs/TechRpts/2008/EECS-2008-41.html
After verification, remove all links between iRobot Ctrl and Slope. Then design sensor/actuator controllers based on the contract offered by the environment. Also, do the refinement for states in the controller for operations irrelevant to control. Establish links between sensor/actuator controllers and iRobot Ctrl. Lastly, perform code generation on the grey part, and we can have the control software installed to iRobot Create.
NOTE: slight modifications (without changing functionalities) must be made for successful code generation. This is because we are using SDF code generator (for this simple case SR is equal to SDF). Please see the file iRobotCreateCodeGenExperimental.xml for details.

property.name: text
property.value: The desired behavior is to have the robot reach the flat surface. This property can be specified with CTL formula indicated as follows: AF (Slope.state = Goal)

property.name: text
property.value: This example does not simulate. It is intended for verification only at this point.

property.name: text
property.value:
Since the environment is discrete into grids, we use numbers to indicate directions of the head. HeadDirection = 0 : N HeadDirection = 1 : NE HeadDirection = 2 : E HeadDirection = 3 : SE HeadDirection = 4 : S HeadDirection = 5 : SW HeadDirection = 6 : W HeadDirection = 7 : NW
(Patrick: This is a smaller board, since the laptop would run out of memory)
The environment represents a 60 unit wide & 60 (originally 120) unit height board. The radius of the iRobot is 16 units. Therefore, if the center of mass of the iRobot reaches XPosition == 16, it can not move to left any further. Otherwise it may fall down from the edge. Similarily, if the center of mass of the iRobot reaches XPosition == 44, it can not move to right any further. Otherwise it may fall down from the edge. The "Risk" state represents the fact that the robot has the potential to fall. However, when it is in the edge, it can turn in place to escape. This is because we assume that only cliff detection sensors are used.
We use CenterH0 to represent the robot is in the center area and its heading is North. It would send events indicating its direction and situation where no edges are detected. We use CResponse0 to represent the waiting of instructions under the situation. When performing model checking, we need to set up the initial state correctly.
Note: the separation of sending states and receiving states is necessary.

property.name: embeddedCode
text
property.value: The contract offered by the environment is that environment would only send readings in either high, mid or low. Therefore, although the accelerometer may be powerful enough to have very fine readings, we still need to partition the domain into three.

property.name: embeddedCode
text
property.value:
The actuator should try to guarantee the "contract" offered by the environment: (1) When RotateCW occurs, it turns 45 degree clockwise (2) When RotateCCW occurs, it turns 45 degree counterclockwise (3) When it is heading NE, SW, NW, SE, it drives both 1.414 units both horizontally and vertically. If it is heading N,E,S,W, it drives 1 unit.
Therefore, our implementation tries to drive 7 unit no matter what direction it is heading. It is a close approximation when the unit is small enough, and can be viewed as obeying the contract.

property.name: embeddedCode
embeddedCode
embeddedCode
text
property.value:
For this simple robotic controller, it tries to perform hill climbing and avoid falling from edges. Theoretically, given signals offered by the environment, the robot can be aware of its heading direction. Here we simply implement a reactive controller, and try to apply formal verification to see if it satisfies the spec.
First, it tries to rotate to up. When EdgeLeft event is present, it first rotates clockwise until NoEdgeLeft is present, then continuously rotate clockwise until it is facing up (N, NE, NW), and drive the robot until (1) another edge is encountered or (2) The flat surface is reached. Similarily, the robot would rotate counterclockwise when EdgeRight is present.
The possible behavior would be climbing up the hill with zig-zag fashion.
